artists.name: Ned Kahn
artists.bio: Ned Kahn creates large-scale artworks that make the invisible forces of nature visible. His wind, water, and mist sculptures respond to their environments in real time, transforming buildings and public spaces into dynamic canvases shaped by weather and atmosphere.

artists.name: Olafur Eliasson
artists.bio: Olafur Eliasson uses light, water, and temperature to create immersive environments that challenge perception and connect viewers to the natural world. His installations in major museums and public spaces worldwide explore the boundaries between art, architecture, and nature.

artists.name: James Turrell
artists.bio: James Turrell works directly with light and space to create artworks that engage viewers with the limits and wonder of human perception. His Roden Crater project in Arizona transforms an extinct volcanic cinder cone into a monumental naked-eye observatory.

artists.name: Andy Goldsworthy
artists.bio: Andy Goldsworthy creates site-specific sculptures and land art using natural materials found on-site — leaves, stones, ice, mud, and branches. His ephemeral works celebrate the cycles of growth, decay, and renewal inherent in the natural world.

artists.name: Nils-Udo
artists.bio: Nils-Udo is a pioneer of art in nature who has been creating large-scale installations using living plants, earth, and water since the 1960s. His works, often documented only through photography, transform forests and landscapes into dreamlike compositions.

artists.name: Robert Smithson
artists.bio: Robert Smithson was a pivotal figure in the Land Art movement, best known for Spiral Jetty on the Great Salt Lake. His monumental earthworks and writings redefined the relationship between art, landscape, entropy, and geological time.

artists.name: Walter De Maria
artists.bio: Walter De Maria created minimalist sculptures and installations that harness the sublime power of natural phenomena — particularly lightning, earth, and vast open spaces. His works are experiences of elemental forces at a monumental scale.

artists.name: Jeppe Hein
artists.bio: Jeppe Hein creates interactive, playful art installations that use water, fire, mirrors, and movement to engage audiences. His works blur the line between sculpture and social space, inviting direct physical participation.

artists.name: Janet Echelman
artists.bio: Janet Echelman sculpts at the scale of buildings and city blocks using lightweight fiber nets that reshape with the wind. Her billowing, colorful aerial sculptures transform urban landscapes and invite people to look up.

artists.name: Maya Lin
artists.bio: Maya Lin is an artist and architect whose environmental installations and memorials explore the relationship between landscape and memory. Her work draws on topography, water systems, and natural forms to create contemplative spaces.

artists.name: Tomás Saraceno
artists.bio: Tomás Saraceno builds airborne sculptures and interactive installations inspired by spider webs, soap bubbles, and atmospheric phenomena. His visionary projects explore sustainable flight and interspecies collaboration.

artists.name: Anthony Howe
artists.bio: Anthony Howe creates mesmerizing wind-driven kinetic sculptures from stainless steel. His works, which move with the slightest breeze, appear to breathe and pulse like living organisms, blurring the line between engineering and organic form.

artists.name: Fujiko Nakaya
artists.bio: Fujiko Nakaya is a pioneer of fog sculpture, creating immersive environments from water vapor since the 1970s. Daughter of physicist Ukichiro Nakaya who created the first artificial snowflakes, she became the first artist to sculpt with fog at Expo '70 in Osaka.

artists.name: Theo Jansen
artists.bio: Theo Jansen creates wind-powered kinetic sculptures called Strandbeests — 'beach animals' built from PVC tubing that walk autonomously on Dutch beaches. He describes them as a new form of artificial life, blurring the boundaries between art, engineering, and biology.

artists.name: Peter Richards
artists.bio: Peter Richards is a Senior Artist at the Exploratorium in San Francisco, best known for The Wave Organ — a wave-activated acoustic sculpture on San Francisco Bay. His work explores the intersection of natural forces and sound.

artists.name: Reuben Margolin
artists.bio: Reuben Margolin creates large-scale kinetic wave sculptures using pure mechanics — cables, pulleys, and motors — to produce mesmerizing wave motions. His works translate mathematical wave equations into physical, moving forms.

artists.name: Nancy Holt
artists.bio: Nancy Holt was a pioneering land artist who created monumental site-specific works aligning architecture with astronomical phenomena — sunlight, starlight, and the rhythms of the cosmos. Her concrete tunnels, pools, and observatories frame the sky itself as the artwork.

artists.name: Michael Heizer
artists.bio: Michael Heizer is one of the founders of the Land Art movement, creating monumental earthworks in the American desert that challenge art to exist beyond galleries at a superhuman scale. His works displace hundreds of thousands of tons of earth and rock.

artists.name: Agnes Denes
artists.bio: Agnes Denes is a visionary conceptual artist whose monumental earthworks and environmental interventions have made her a pioneer of ecological art. Her works plant living systems in unlikely places — wheat in Manhattan, forests on reclaimed land — confronting humanity's relationship with nature.

artists.name: Patrick Dougherty
artists.bio: Patrick Dougherty spent three decades building over 300 monumental sculptures worldwide by weaving freshly cut tree saplings into soaring, organic architectural forms. His ephemeral stickwork installations blur the line between sculpture and shelter.

artists.name: Cai Guo-Qiang
artists.bio: Cai Guo-Qiang harnesses the elemental power of gunpowder and fire to create explosive artworks that momentarily reshape the sky. His work draws on centuries of Chinese pyrotechnic tradition to transform destruction into transcendent, ephemeral beauty.

artists.name: George Rickey
artists.bio: George Rickey was one of the most important kinetic sculptors of the twentieth century, creating geometric abstractions in stainless steel engineered to move with the slightest air currents. His sculptures — powered solely by wind and gravity, never by motors — translate invisible atmospheric forces into slow, hypnotic choreography.

artists.name: Susumu Shingu
artists.bio: Susumu Shingu transforms wind and water into poetry through elegantly engineered kinetic sculptures installed across six continents. Originally trained as a painter, he became captivated by the wind's potential when a canvas he hung outdoors began to move.

artists.name: Luke Jerram
artists.bio: Luke Jerram is a multidisciplinary artist whose installations transform public spaces into sites of wonder, using precise NASA imagery and scientific data to create immersive encounters with celestial bodies. His touring artworks have reached over 10 million viewers worldwide.

artists.name: Cristina Iglesias
artists.bio: Cristina Iglesias creates immersive sculptural environments where water, bronze, and architecture converge to reveal hidden forces beneath our feet. Her monumental public works transform plazas and buildings into living thresholds where water surges through intricately cast bronze landscapes.

artists.name: Bill Fontana
artists.bio: Bill Fontana is a pioneering sound sculptor who has spent over five decades revealing the hidden music of natural and architectural environments using microphones, accelerometers, and real-time audio networks. His installations transform how we perceive places by relocating sounds of nature into unexpected contexts.

artists.name: Christo and Jeanne-Claude
artists.bio: Christo Vladimirov Javacheff and Jeanne-Claude Denat de Guillebon, both born on the same day in 1935, created monumental environmental artworks that transformed landscapes and iconic structures by wrapping them in fabric. Their large-scale, site-specific installations surrounded islands in pink polypropylene, draped entire coastlines, and turned Central Park into a saffron river of billowing gates.

artists.name: Richard Long
artists.bio: Sir Richard Long is a pioneering British land artist who has made walking itself an art form since 1967, creating sculptures from stones, mud, and the traces of his footsteps across landscapes from the Sahara to the Himalayas. His geometric arrangements of natural materials and his mud paintings distill the essence of a journey into timeless, elemental forms.

artists.name: Jim Denevan
artists.bio: Jim Denevan creates monumental ephemeral land art by drawing vast geometric and Fibonacci-inspired compositions on beaches, dry lake beds, and frozen lakes using nothing more than a stick or rake. His sand drawings, which can span miles and are erased by tides or wind, include the world's largest single artwork created on the frozen surface of Siberia's Lake Baikal.

artists.name: Cornelia Konrads
artists.bio: Cornelia Konrads creates gravity-defying site-specific installations in forests, parks, and gardens worldwide, using found natural materials such as stones, branches, and logs that appear to float, disintegrate, or defy physics. Her works merge seamlessly with their surroundings, transforming landscapes into places of magical suspension between the earthbound and the ethereal.

artists.name: Charles Jencks
artists.bio: Charles Jencks was a cultural theorist and landscape architect who created massive earthwork gardens inspired by modern cosmology, fractal geometry, and the story of the universe. His monumental landform sculptures in Scotland, including the Garden of Cosmic Speculation and Crawick Multiverse, reshape terrain into spiraling hills and sculpted lakes that embody scientific narratives at a breathtaking scale.

artists.name: Nikolay Polissky
artists.bio: Nikolay Polissky builds towering, fantastical structures from natural and rural materials in the Russian village of Nikola-Lenivets, collaborating with local villagers to transform the landscape into one of Europe's most remarkable land art parks. His monumental sculptures woven from willow, birch, and hay blend folk craft traditions with contemporary art, and he founded the Archstoyanie festival which has turned a semi-abandoned village into a world-famous cultural destination.

artists.name: Martin Hill
artists.bio: Martin Hill creates ephemeral circular environmental sculptures in the wild landscapes of New Zealand and around the world, collaborating with partner Philippa Jones since 1994. Using ice, stone, plants, and other natural materials that return to nature after being photographed, his work embodies the principles of a circular economy and the interconnectedness of the web of life.

artworks.title: Wind Veil
artworks.description: A massive curtain of 80,000 small aluminum plates mounted on the facade of the Technorama science center. The panels ripple and shimmer in response to wind currents, making invisible air patterns visible as waves of light and shadow cascade across the building's surface.

artworks.title: The Weather Project
artworks.description: A giant artificial sun made of mono-frequency lamps and a ceiling-spanning mirror filled the vast Turbine Hall at Tate Modern. Visitors lay on the floor gazing at their reflections, creating an extraordinary communal experience of manufactured weather and light.

artworks.title: Ice Watch
artworks.description: Twelve massive blocks of glacial ice harvested from a fjord in Greenland were arranged in a clock formation in public squares. Visitors could touch and watch the ancient ice melt in real time — a visceral, poetic confrontation with climate change.
artworks.location: City Hall Square, Copenhagen / Place du Panthéon, Paris
materials: Glacial ice from Nuup Kangerlua fjord

artworks.title: New York City Waterfalls
artworks.description: Four massive artificial waterfalls, ranging from 27 to 37 meters tall, installed along New York's East River waterfront. The temporary public art project created dramatic cascades of water visible from Brooklyn, Manhattan, and passing ferries.
artworks.location: East River, New York City, USA

artworks.title: Your Rainbow Panorama
artworks.description: A circular walkway of colored glass panels spanning the entire visible spectrum installed on the rooftop of the ARoS Museum. Visitors walk through a 150-meter rainbow loop, seeing the city of Aarhus transformed through every color of light.
exhibitions: Permanent installation at ARoS Aarhus Art Museum

artworks.title: Roden Crater
artworks.description: James Turrell's life work: transforming an extinct volcanic cinder cone in Arizona's Painted Desert into a monumental naked-eye observatory. Tunnels, chambers, and apertures frame celestial events — sunrise, sunset, moonrise, and the movements of stars — as pure experiences of light and space.

artworks.title: Aten Reign
artworks.description: A site-specific installation transforming the rotunda of the Guggenheim Museum into a luminous volume of slowly shifting colored light. Concentric ellipses of LED light fill the spiraling space, creating an overwhelming experience of pure color and transcendence.
artworks.location: Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New York, USA

artworks.title: Twilight Epiphany
artworks.description: A pyramidal skyspace pavilion with a retractable roof that frames the sky as a canvas of light. At dawn and dusk, LED sequences wash the interior with color while the sky shifts overhead, creating a meditative experience of celestial transition.

artworks.title: Storm King Wall
artworks.description: A sinuous dry stone wall that winds through fields and woodland at Storm King Art Center, at one point diving into a pond and emerging on the other side. The 750-meter wall follows the natural contours of the landscape, appearing to flow like a river of stone.
artworks.location: Storm King Art Center, New York, USA
exhibitions: Permanent installation at Storm King Art Center

artworks.title: Cairn
artworks.description: An egg-shaped cairn built from carefully balanced slate and stone, part of Goldsworthy's series of cairns placed in dramatic landscapes. These stacked stone forms reference ancient markers while exploring the tension between permanence and fragility.
exhibitions: National Gallery of Art, Washington D.C.

artworks.title: Spiral Jetty
artworks.description: The most iconic earthwork ever created: a 460-meter counterclockwise coil of mud, basalt, and salt crystals extending into the Great Salt Lake. The jetty rises and disappears with water levels, its black basalt encrusted with white salt crystals, constantly transformed by the lake's ecology.
artworks.location: Rozel Point, Great Salt Lake, Utah, USA
exhibitions: Permanent earthwork, maintained by Dia Art Foundation

artworks.title: Broken Circle / Spiral Hill
artworks.description: A two-part earthwork created for the Sonsbeek exhibition: a broken circle of sand and water in a quarry lake, paired with a spiral hill on its shore. The only Smithson earthwork in Europe, it plays with positive and negative space, land and water, ascent and enclosure.

artworks.title: Partially Buried Woodshed
artworks.description: Twenty truckloads of earth were poured onto a woodshed at Kent State University until its central beam cracked and buckled. The work embodies Smithson's concept of entropy — the irreversible process of decay and collapse that governs all structures.
exhibitions: Kent State University, 1970 (structure has since deteriorated)

artworks.title: The Lightning Field
artworks.description: 400 stainless steel poles arranged in a precise rectangular grid across a remote high desert plain in New Mexico. The poles attract lightning during storms, creating spectacular natural light shows, though the piece is equally powerful in calm weather as the poles catch sunlight and seem to dissolve into the landscape.
exhibitions: Permanent installation, Dia Art Foundation (overnight visits by appointment)

artworks.title: The New York Earth Room
artworks.description: 127,300 kilograms of dark, moist earth fill a pristine white SoHo loft to a depth of 56 centimeters. The rich smell of soil and the surreal sight of an interior landscape occupying a Manhattan apartment create a powerful sensory dislocation between urban life and the natural world.
artworks.location: 141 Wooster Street, New York City, USA
artworks.dimensions: 335 sq meters of floor covered 56cm deep
exhibitions: Permanent installation, open since 1980, maintained by Dia Art Foundation

artworks.title: The Broken Kilometer
artworks.description: 500 highly polished brass rods, each 2 meters long, arranged in five parallel rows across a SoHo loft. The spacing between rods increases progressively, creating a visual compression that plays with perspective and the viewer's perception of depth and distance.
artworks.location: 393 West Broadway, New York City, USA

artworks.title: Appearing Rooms
artworks.description: A fountain sculpture made of precisely controlled water jets that form and dissolve transparent walls of water, creating four rooms that appear and disappear in a choreographed sequence. Visitors can enter the rooms and experience being momentarily enclosed by walls of falling water.

artworks.title: Modified Social Benches
artworks.description: A series of park benches modified into absurd, playful, and challenging forms — curved, twisted, looped, spiked, or impossibly angled. Each bench questions how public furniture shapes social behavior and invites passersby into unexpected physical interactions.

artworks.title: Fire Fountain
artworks.description: A fountain that alternates between shooting water and fire from the same jets, creating a mesmerizing dance of opposing elements. The work transforms a traditional architectural element into a spectacle of elemental contradiction.

Named for the 1.78 microseconds by which the 2011 Japanese earthquake shortened the day, this monumental aerial sculpture spans over a city block in Boston. Woven from ultra-high-molecular-weight polyethylene fiber stronger than steel, it billows and transforms with wind and is illuminated in shifting colors at night.
exhibitions: Permanent installation on the Rose Kennedy Greenway, Boston

artworks.title: She Changes
artworks.description: A permanent monumental net sculpture at the Porto roundabout near the sea, inspired by the city's fishing heritage. The red and gold nets billow in the ocean winds, constantly changing shape, resembling a massive jellyfish or sea creature floating above the traffic circle.

artworks.title: Skies Painted with Unnumbered Sparks
artworks.description: A massive aerial sculpture suspended between buildings at the TED conference in Vancouver. At night, attendees could choreograph the sculpture's lighting using their smartphones, transforming the collective gestures of hundreds of people into flowing patterns of light across the fiber canopy.

artworks.title: Earthtime 1.26
artworks.description: A monumental aerial sculpture that visualizes the tsunami wave heights caused by the 2010 Chilean earthquake. The net's form was generated from NASA data of the tsunami's propagation across the Pacific Ocean, translating scientific data into a breathtaking physical form.

artworks.title: Vietnam Veterans Memorial
artworks.description: A V-shaped wall of polished black granite inscribed with the names of 58,318 Americans who died in the Vietnam War. The reflective surface merges visitors' reflections with the names, while the wall emerges from and returns to the earth, creating a wound in the landscape that heals through remembrance.
exhibitions: Permanent memorial, National Mall, Washington D.C.

artworks.title: Wave Field
artworks.description: An undulating landscape of grass-covered earth waves that transforms a flat lawn into a rolling sea of green. The precisely sculpted mounds mimic ocean waves frozen mid-motion, creating a meditative landscape that visitors can walk through and recline upon.
artworks.location: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, USA
exhibitions: Permanent installation at University of Michigan

artworks.title: Lucea
artworks.description: A large-scale wind-driven kinetic sculpture of curved stainless steel fins that rotate around a central axis. In even light breezes, the sculpture comes alive with hypnotic, organic-seeming motion — the fins appear to breathe and pulse like a living deep-sea organism.

artworks.title: Olympic Cauldron (Rio 2016)
artworks.description: The kinetic sculpture for the 2016 Rio Olympics cauldron — a sun-shaped kinetic sculpture with radiating petals that rotated in the wind above the Olympic flame. Seen by billions during the opening ceremony, it became an iconic symbol of the games, combining fire, wind, and sculptural motion.
exhibitions: Permanent display in Rio de Janeiro

artworks.title: Der Turm (The Tower)
artworks.description: A monumental tower structure built from natural materials — branches, earth, and living plants — rising from the forest floor in Frenswegen, Germany. Part of the Kunstwegen sculpture trail, this permanent outdoor work embodies Nils-Udo's vision of architecture grown from nature itself.
exhibitions: Permanent installation on Kunstwegen sculpture trail, Nordhorn

artworks.title: Earth Art
artworks.description: A land art installation using natural materials arranged directly in the landscape. Nils-Udo's earth artworks transform found natural elements into composed forms that blur the boundary between sculpture and landscape, art and ecology.

artworks.title: Cloud Cities
artworks.description: Interconnected transparent spheres and geometric structures suspended in space, creating inhabitable cloud-like formations. First shown at Hamburger Bahnhof in Berlin and later at Torre Glòries in Barcelona, these floating architectures envision a future of airborne living inspired by soap bubbles and spider webs.
artworks.location: Hamburger Bahnhof, Berlin / Torre Glòries, Barcelona

artworks.title: Connectome
artworks.description: A sprawling web-like installation of interconnected threads and nodes that visualizes the neural networks of the brain and the cosmic web of the universe. Saraceno draws parallels between spider webs, neural pathways, and the large-scale structure of the cosmos, proposing radical interconnection as a fundamental principle.

artworks.title: Outdoor Sculpture at Domaine du Muy
artworks.description: A large-scale outdoor sculpture installed in the grounds of Domaine du Muy in southern France. The reflective, geometric structure interacts with sunlight and the natural landscape, embodying Saraceno's ongoing exploration of lightweight architecture and solar energy.
exhibitions: Permanent installation at Domaine du Muy

artworks.title: Tornado
artworks.description: A controlled vortex of mist created inside a transparent chamber. Using fans and ultrasonic foggers, Kahn generates a real tornado visible from all angles — a captivating demonstration of fluid dynamics and atmospheric science made tangible.
exhibitions: Permanent installation at Exploratorium, San Francisco

artworks.title: Wave Oculus
artworks.description: An enormous circular wave pool installed in the ceiling of a building atrium. Water moves in slow, mesmerizing wave patterns visible from below through a glass oculus, creating an ever-changing liquid mandala overhead.

artworks.title: Cloud Arbor
artworks.description: A grove of tree-like structures that emit clouds of fine mist from their canopies. Visitors walk beneath a manufactured fog layer that responds to wind conditions, creating an immersive microclimate experience.
exhibitions: Permanent installation at Children's Museum of Pittsburgh

artworks.title: Rowan Leaves and Hole
artworks.description: A spiral arrangement of autumn rowan leaves grading from green at the edges through yellow and orange to a deep black void at the center. The leaves were pinned together with thorns in a precise color gradient that appears to descend into infinite darkness.

artworks.title: Icicle Star
artworks.description: Icicles carefully joined together with saliva and frozen breath to form a radiating star shape. Created in bitter cold, this ephemeral sculpture lasted only until the sun warmed it, embodying Goldsworthy's philosophy of working within nature's cycles of creation and dissolution.
exhibitions: Photographed in situ, documented in 'Andy Goldsworthy: A Collaboration with Nature'

artworks.title: The Nest
artworks.description: One of Nils-Udo's earliest and most iconic works: an enormous bird's nest built from earth, stones, and branches in a Bavarian forest clearing, large enough for a human to lie inside. The work invites contemplation of our place within the natural world.

artworks.title: Clemson Clay Nest
artworks.description: A monumental nest-like structure woven from branches and natural materials, set within a forest clearing. The oversized nest cradles elements of the landscape, creating a surreal meeting point between human-scale art and the nurturing forms found in nature.

artworks.title: In Orbit
artworks.description: A vast installation of interconnected transparent spheres and net levels suspended 25 meters above the ground in the K21 museum. Visitors can climb into the nets and walk among the spheres, experiencing the sensation of floating in space while seeing other visitors below and above as tiny figures.

artworks.title: Aerocene
artworks.description: A series of solar-powered aerosolar sculptures that float using only the heat of the sun and infrared radiation from the Earth's surface — no fossil fuels, batteries, or helium. The project envisions a new era of emission-free flight and has set world records for solar-powered human flight.

artworks.title: Storm King Wavefield
artworks.description: Maya Lin's largest wave field: seven rows of undulating earth waves rippling across an 11-acre meadow at Storm King Art Center. The monumental earthwork transforms the Hudson Valley landscape into a frozen ocean, its scale only fully appreciable from above or when walking among its grassy swells.
artworks.location: Storm King Art Center, New York, USA
exhibitions: Permanent installation at Storm King Art Center

artworks.title: Di-Octo
artworks.description: A double-layered kinetic sculpture with eight arms on each layer that counter-rotate in the wind. The two layers create complex, mesmerizing interference patterns as they spin at different speeds, producing an almost digital-looking moiré effect from purely mechanical motion.

artworks.title: Smoking Bench
artworks.description: A sleek minimalist bench that suddenly begins to emit clouds of steam when someone sits on it. The unexpected vapor transforms a mundane act of sitting into a surprising, humorous, and slightly surreal public experience.

artworks.title: Fire Vortex
artworks.description: A 6-meter-tall vortex of swirling fire forms over a pool of burning kerosene in a dark atrium. Fans and blowers create a spinning column of flame that spirals upward, leaving a hollow calm at its center. Visitors view from a balcony and can feel the heat and hear the rumbling of the flames.

artworks.title: Captured Cloud
artworks.description: Between two semicircular steel walls, over 300 mist nozzles produce an artificial cloud that visitors can walk through. The cloud drifts with the wind through the outdoor park, creating a mystical atmosphere that makes the invisible movements of air tangible.
exhibitions: Permanent installation at Technorama Outdoors, Winterthur

artworks.title: Water Vortex
artworks.description: A 6-meter-diameter stainless steel basin filled through angled inlets that direct water in a circular motion, creating a dramatic whirlpool. When full, the water supply stops, the vortex calms, and the basin slowly empties before the cycle restarts — visualizing natural water phenomena in a mesmerizing loop.
exhibitions: Permanent installation at Technorama Outdoors, Winterthur

artworks.title: Fog Bridge #72494
artworks.description: A 150-foot pedestrian bridge lined with over 800 fog nozzles that emit dense clouds of water vapor every half hour. The fog interacts with San Francisco Bay winds, constantly reshaping into new forms. Originally temporary, it became permanent due to enormous popularity. A desalination system conditions bay water for the artwork.

artworks.title: Fog Sculpture #08025
artworks.description: A permanent fog installation at the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao that periodically shrouds Frank Gehry's titanium-clad building in dense artificial fog. The mist transforms the iconic architecture into an ethereal, dissolving form, making the building appear to breathe and vanish into the landscape.
exhibitions: Permanent installation at Guggenheim Museum Bilbao

artworks.title: Strandbeest
artworks.description: Wind-powered kinetic 'beach animals' built from PVC piping, wood, and fabric sails that walk autonomously on Dutch beaches. More sophisticated versions store compressed air for calm moments, detect and retreat from water, and anchor themselves in storms. Jansen has been evolving these creatures for over 30 years, describing them as a new form of life.

artworks.title: The Wave Organ
artworks.description: A wave-activated acoustic sculpture built on a jetty in San Francisco Bay. 25 organ pipes made of PVC and concrete are set at various elevations to accommodate tides. Ocean waves push air and water through the pipes, producing haunting, ever-changing sounds. The jetty itself is built from granite and marble salvaged from a demolished cemetery.

artworks.title: Magic Wave
artworks.description: One of the most complex kinetic sculptures in the world: a light blue aluminum grid suspended by 256 cables, animated by 3,000 pulleys, 5 kilometers of steel cable, and 9 motors. Using pure mechanics rather than computers, the sculpture produces four overlapping wave patterns that create almost limitless figurative shapes in constant, mesmerizing motion.

artworks.title: Sun Tunnels
artworks.description: Four massive concrete cylinders, each 18 feet long and 9 feet in diameter, arranged in an open cross formation in Utah's Great Basin Desert. Precisely aligned with the summer and winter solstice sunrise and sunset, each tunnel is perforated with holes corresponding to the constellations Capricorn, Columba, Draco, and Perseus, casting star patterns of light inside.
exhibitions: Permanent installation, Great Basin Desert, Utah

artworks.title: Dark Star Park
artworks.description: An urban park featuring five large gunite spheres, two reflecting pools, metal poles, and permanent shadow patterns embedded in steel on the ground. Each August 1st at 9:32 AM, the actual shadows cast by the poles and spheres align perfectly with the embedded shadow patterns, marking the date in 1860 when the land was first purchased.

artworks.title: Double Negative
artworks.description: Two enormous trenches cut into facing cliff edges of Mormon Mesa, each 50 feet deep and 30 feet wide, spanning a combined 1,500 feet in length. Created by displacing 244,000 tons of rhyolite and sandstone, the sculpture is the void itself — defining space through absence while framing the desert sky and distant landscape.
exhibitions: Permanent installation, owned by MOCA Los Angeles

artworks.title: Levitated Mass
artworks.description: A 340-ton granite megalith suspended over a 456-foot-long concrete slot carved into LACMA's north lawn, creating the illusion that the massive boulder floats weightlessly above visitors who walk beneath it. The boulder was transported 105 miles over eleven nights from a quarry in Riverside County.
artworks.location: Los Angeles County Museum of Art, Los Angeles, USA

artworks.title: City
artworks.description: The largest contemporary artwork ever built, spanning over a mile and a quarter long and a quarter mile wide in a remote Nevada desert valley. Composed of shaped mounds, depressions, and geometric forms made of compacted dirt, rock, and concrete, City draws on ancient Mesoamerican ceremonial architecture and took 50 years to complete.
artworks.location: Garden Valley, Lincoln County, Nevada, USA
exhibitions: Opened September 2, 2022; limited to 6 visitors per day

artworks.title: Wheatfield — A Confrontation
artworks.description: A 2-acre field of golden wheat planted and harvested on the Battery Park landfill in lower Manhattan, two blocks from Wall Street and adjacent to the World Trade Center. Over four months, 285 hand-furrowed rows grew and yielded nearly 1,000 pounds of grain — a powerful symbol of food, energy, and mismanagement on some of the most valuable real estate on Earth.
artworks.location: Battery Park landfill, Manhattan, New York, USA

artworks.title: Tree Mountain — A Living Time Capsule
artworks.description: A monumental earthwork on a human-made mountain 420 meters long, 270 meters wide, and 38 meters high, planted with 11,000 Finnish pine trees by 11,000 people from around the world. Commissioned at the 1992 Earth Summit and protected for four centuries, each planter received an inheritable certificate valid for 20+ generations.

artworks.title: The Living Pyramid
artworks.description: A 30-foot-tall stepped pyramid of stacked wooden terraces filled with soil and planted with thousands of living grasses and flowering annuals, misted by a revolving sprinkler at the apex. Over the exhibition, plants sprouted, flowered, and died, embodying evolution and regeneration.
artworks.location: Socrates Sculpture Park, Long Island City, New York, USA

artworks.title: Shindig
artworks.description: Ten towering teardrop-shaped forms made of woven willow saplings installed inside the Renwick Gallery as part of the exhibition 'Wonder.' The whimsical structures flash, careen, and rebound across walls and ceiling, suggesting seeds sending up tendrils to find light.
artworks.location: Renwick Gallery, Smithsonian, Washington, D.C., USA

artworks.title: The Royals
artworks.description: A site-specific installation of woven sapling structures nestled among the tropical gardens of McKee Botanical Garden, built over three weeks with community volunteers. The organic, towering forms rise from the earth like fantastical architecture grown from the surrounding vegetation.
artworks.location: McKee Botanical Garden, Vero Beach, Florida, USA

artworks.title: Sky Ladder
artworks.description: A 500-meter-tall ladder of fire ascending into the pre-dawn sky, lifted by a helium balloon. Coated in quick-burning fuses and gold fireworks, the 5.5-meter-wide ladder blazed for 2.5 minutes — a gift for the artist's 100-year-old grandmother, realized after three failed attempts over two decades.
artworks.location: Huiyu Island Harbour, Quanzhou, Fujian, China

artworks.title: Transient Rainbow
artworks.description: A monumental arc of 1,000 computer-chip-fitted fireworks creating a rainbow 500 feet wide and 120 feet high over the East River between Manhattan and Queens. Traveling at 100 feet per second, the thundering rainbow lasted just 15 seconds, realized for the opening of MoMA's temporary Queens location.

artworks.title: Footprints of History
artworks.description: Twenty-nine giant firework 'footprints' flew sequentially over the Beijing skyline during the Opening Ceremony of the 2008 Olympic Games, tracing a path from the ancient city center to the Bird's Nest Stadium. Each footprint symbolized one of the 29 Olympiads, creating an explosive visual narrative before a global audience of billions.

artworks.title: Four Squares in a Square
artworks.description: Four large stainless steel squares rotating independently on a central pivot, their movements dictated entirely by wind. Commissioned for Mies van der Rohe's Neue Nationalgalerie plaza in Berlin, the sculpture's slow, unpredictable choreography creates an ever-changing geometric composition against the sky.

artworks.title: Two Lines Oblique
artworks.description: Two 9-meter tapered stainless steel blades balanced on a single point, sweeping through slow, wide arcs driven entirely by wind. The monumental scale and glacial movement create an almost meditative experience of watching invisible air currents made tangible through polished metal.
artworks.location: Empire State Plaza, Albany, New York, USA

artworks.title: Gift of the Wind
artworks.description: A towering kinetic sculpture with three red wings that rotate gracefully in the wind, installed above a subway station. The bright forms spin and dance against the sky, bringing movement and life to the daily commute of thousands of passengers.
artworks.location: Porter Square Station, Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA
exhibitions: Permanent installation, MBTA Porter Square Station

artworks.title: Wind Caravan
artworks.description: Twenty-one wind sculptures exhibited across six countries on six continents, from the Sahara Desert to Antarctica, from Mongolia to the Strait of Magellan. Each sculpture was placed in the world's most extreme wind landscapes, documenting how the same invisible force manifests differently in every environment on Earth.
exhibitions: Morocco, Mongolia, Patagonia, Antarctica, Finland, Japan (2000-2001)

artworks.title: Museum of the Moon
artworks.description: A 7-meter internally illuminated sphere featuring 120dpi detailed NASA imagery of the lunar surface at a scale of 1:500,000, where each centimeter represents 5 kilometers. Presented with a surround sound composition by Dan Jones, the touring installation has been exhibited over 350 times in 40+ countries.

artworks.title: Gaia
artworks.description: A 7-meter slowly revolving Earth sphere using detailed NASA imagery, designed to evoke the Overview Effect — the cognitive shift astronauts experience upon seeing Earth from space. Floating in large interior spaces, it gives viewers a perspective of our planet previously available only from orbit.

artworks.title: Forgotten Streams
artworks.description: A 40-meter bronze riverbed evoking the lost Walbrook River that once flowed beneath the City of London. Water surges and recedes through three intricately cast bronze channels set into the plaza floor of Bloomberg's European headquarters, revealing a hidden aquatic world beneath the surface of the financial district.
exhibitions: Permanent installation, Bloomberg European HQ, London

artworks.title: Tres Aguas
artworks.description: A trilogy of water installations distributed across the historic city of Toledo, Spain: a subterranean pool in the Convent of Santa Clara, a cascading bronze well in the Plaza del Ayuntamiento, and a monumental fountain near the Tagus River. Together they trace water's journey through the ancient city, from source to river.
artworks.dimensions: Three site-specific installations across the city

artworks.title: Landscape Sculpture with Fog Horns
artworks.description: Live audio from eight fog horns positioned around San Francisco Bay was transmitted via telephone lines and broadcast from loudspeakers at Fort Mason. The displaced sounds of distant fog horns created a sculptural soundscape, transforming an urban park into an acoustic landscape of the entire Bay.

artworks.title: Silent Echoes: Notre-Dame
artworks.description: A 10-channel sound installation capturing the hidden acoustic life of Notre-Dame's bells during the cathedral's post-fire restoration. Accelerometers attached to the bells recorded their resonance and decay, bringing the living voice of the damaged cathedral to listeners at the Centre Pompidou.

artworks.title: Surrounded Islands
artworks.description: Eleven islands in Biscayne Bay, Miami, were surrounded with 603,850 square meters of floating pink woven polypropylene fabric that extended 61 meters from each island into the water. The installation, which took over three years to plan and cost $3.5 million self-financed through art sales, was on view for just 11 days in May 1983, creating a stunning flamingo-pink archipelago visible from the air.
artworks.location: Biscayne Bay, Greater Miami, Florida, USA
artworks.dimensions: 6.5 million sq ft of fabric surrounding 11 islands, extending 61m from shore
exhibitions: Perez Art Museum Miami retrospective exhibition

artworks.title: The Floating Piers
artworks.description: A 3-kilometer walkway of shimmering saffron-yellow fabric stretched across Lake Iseo in northern Italy, connecting the town of Sulzano to the islands of Monte Isola and San Paolo. Supported by 226,000 high-density polyethylene cubes and anchored by 220 six-ton anchors at depths up to 92 meters, the 16-meter-wide piers allowed 1.2 million visitors to walk on water over 16 days.
artworks.dimensions: 3 km long, 16 m wide, 35 cm above water
exhibitions: Lake Iseo, Italy, June 18 - July 3, 2016 (16 days)

artworks.title: The Gates
artworks.description: 7,503 steel gates, each 4.87 meters high with free-hanging saffron-colored nylon fabric panels, lined 37 kilometers of pathways through Central Park in New York City. Conceived in 1979 and finally realized 26 years later, the installation used 5,390 tons of steel and 99,155 square meters of fabric, creating a flowing river of color through the winter landscape for 16 days in February 2005.
artworks.location: Central Park, New York City, USA
artworks.dimensions: 7,503 gates, each 4.87m high, spanning 37 km of pathways
exhibitions: Central Park, New York City, February 12-27, 2005 (16 days)

artworks.title: A Line Made by Walking
artworks.description: Created when Long was a 22-year-old art student at Saint Martin's School of Art, this seminal work was made by walking back and forth in a straight line through a field of grass in Wiltshire, England, until the flattened blades formed a visible path, which he then photographed. Considered one of the most important early works in the history of both land art and conceptual art, it proposed that the simple act of walking could be sculpture.
artworks.dimensions: Photograph: 825 x 1125 mm (gelatin silver print on paper)
exhibitions: Included in numerous retrospective exhibitions worldwide

artworks.title: Sahara Circle
artworks.description: During a solitary walk through the Hoggar region of the Sahara in southern Algeria, Long arranged a ring of desert rocks around a circular area he had cleared within a patch of broken stones. The work exemplifies his lifelong practice of creating simple geometric forms in remote landscapes using materials found underfoot, reflecting his belief that circles have belonged to all people at all times.
artworks.dimensions: Variable (documented as photograph, 159 x 1276 mm print at Tate)

artworks.title: South Bank Circle
artworks.description: A large floor sculpture made from pieces of Delabole slate arranged in a circle on the gallery floor. The work brings the raw materials of the English landscape into the formal gallery space, creating a meditative geological presence that evokes ancient stone circles while remaining firmly contemporary in its minimalist arrangement.

artworks.title: Lake Baikal Drawing
artworks.description: The world's largest single artwork, created over 15 days on the frozen surface of Lake Baikal in Siberia, Russia. Denevan and his crew carved a spiral of over one thousand circles arranged along a Fibonacci curve, growing from an origin of 18 inches to several miles in diameter, covering 12.5 square miles of ice. The work was documented in the film Art Hard (2011).

artworks.title: Angle of Repose
artworks.description: Created for Desert X AlUla 2022 in Saudi Arabia, this large-scale sand composition consists of 365 mounds of collected sand radially emerging around a central point. The first concentric circle comprises 26 mounds, each the size of a newborn child, with the composition growing outward. Visitors can walk through the mounds on a contemplative journey as sun, wind, and gravity slowly erode the forms.

artworks.title: Apollonian Gasket, Black Rock Desert
artworks.description: Based on the mathematical theorem called an Apollonian gasket, this monumental drawing on the dry lake bed of Nevada's Black Rock Desert consisted of triples of circles at tangents to others. The drawing took 15 days to complete, measured three miles wide with an overall circumference of nine miles, and at the time was considered the world's largest single artwork before the Lake Baikal project surpassed it.

artworks.title: Passage
artworks.description: Installed at the Centre d'Arts et de Nature at the Domaine de Chaumont-sur-Loire in France, Passage creates a literal pathway back into nature at the border of a forest and the start of a narrow trail. Cut-down branches are returned to the cleared area, mounted upon an iron frame and suspended with steel rope, forming a roughly organized door frame that drifts upward and outward as if the materials are escaping gravity.
exhibitions: Centre d'Arts et de Nature, Domaine de Chaumont-sur-Loire, 2015 Art Season

artworks.title: The Gate
artworks.description: Installed in the forest of Fontainebleau, France, this gravity-defying installation transforms an old stone doorway into something otherworldly. Stones appear to hang weightless in mid-air as they crumble away from existing stonework, streaming upward from the weathered posts of an abandoned entrance as if caught in a moment of ethereal disintegration.

artworks.title: Trans-Piles
artworks.description: Part of the artist's ongoing 'Piles' series, Trans-Piles features conical stacks of stones and wood that appear to dissolve into the air, with materials streaming upward from the top of each pile as if evaporating into the sky. Inspired by the wishing stone cones of Asian shamanic traditions older than Buddhism, the work plays with gravity, dissolution, and the boundary between nature and culture.
exhibitions: Various international sculpture parks and land art exhibitions

artworks.title: Garden of Cosmic Speculation
artworks.description: A 12-hectare (30-acre) sculpture garden at Portrack House in Dumfriesshire, Scotland, created by Jencks with his late wife Maggie Keswick Jencks. The garden features over twenty areas designed around scientific and mathematical metaphors, including a DNA garden, Quark Walk, Fractal Terrace, and spiraling landform mounds sculpted from the earth, with each element telling part of the story of the cosmos from the Big Bang to human consciousness.
exhibitions: Open to the public one day per year for Scotland's Gardens Scheme

artworks.title: Crawick Multiverse
artworks.description: Jencks's largest work in Britain, this 55-acre landscape artwork was created on the site of a former open-cast coal mine near Sanquhar in Dumfries and Galloway, Scotland. Nine monumental landforms constructed from earth and 2,000 boulders found on the site represent cosmological themes including galaxies, comets, the sun, black holes, and the speculative multiverse, connected by a network of paths. Opened on the summer solstice 2015, it is free and open to the public.
artworks.location: Sanquhar, Dumfries and Galloway, Scotland, UK

artworks.title: Cells of Life
artworks.description: Eight sculptural landforms and a connecting causeway surround four lakes and a flat parterre at Jupiter Artland near Edinburgh. Developed from 2003 to 2010, the earthworks reference the cellular process of mitosis, with hill formations sculpted into layered spirals that, seen from above, present the early stages of cell division into membranes and nuclei, marking the entrance to the sculpture park.
artworks.location: Jupiter Artland, Bonnington House, near Edinburgh, Scotland, UK
artworks.dimensions: Eight landforms surrounding four lakes, site-scale
exhibitions: Permanent installation at Jupiter Artland, opened 2010

artworks.title: Snowmen
artworks.description: The first land art project in Nikola-Lenivets and the work that launched Polissky's career as a land artist. After envisioning hundreds of snowmen on the high bank of the Ugra River, Polissky enlisted villagers to build approximately 220 snow figures on the sloping riverbank, creating an army of snowmen marching over the winter fields. This collaborative process with local residents became the model for all his subsequent work.

artworks.title: Beaubourg (Bobur)
artworks.description: A towering 22-meter (72-foot) sculpture resembling a cluster of organ pipes or trumpeting elephants, constructed from birch twigs woven onto a metal skeleton using traditional Russian basket-weaving techniques. Inspired by the architecture of the Centre Pompidou in Paris, the structure contains a spiral staircase inside leading to an observation deck at the top, offering panoramic views over the Nikola-Lenivets landscape.
artworks.location: Nikola-Lenivets Art Park, Kaluga Region, Russia
exhibitions: Permanent installation at Nikola-Lenivets Art Park

artworks.title: Universal Mind
artworks.description: The largest installation ever created by Polissky, Universal Mind is a gigantic sculpture of two hemispheres representing a mechanical brain, 14 meters in diameter, made of curved wooden beams with mirror plates. Part of his scientific series, the sculpture sits on a pedestal and at night comes alive as pulsating lights simulate billions of racing neurons, combining traditional natural materials with a wholly new vision of monumental wooden sculpture.
artworks.location: Nikola-Lenivets Art Park, Kaluga Region, Russia
exhibitions: Permanent installation at Nikola-Lenivets Art Park, 2012

artworks.title: Synergy
artworks.description: A tensegrity sculpture made from raupo stems (bulrush) interconnected by a network of flax threads, using nature's universal construction system where none of the stems touch and are held under compression by tension from the threads. The sculpture was photographed floating in the calm shallows of Lake Wanaka at sunset, its reflection in the still water completing the circular form that is central to Hill's artistic philosophy.
exhibitions: Documented as photograph in 'Fine Line' publication

artworks.title: Stone Circle
artworks.description: Using the natural buoyancy of pumice stones found on the shore of Lake Taupo, New Zealand, Hill threaded the lightweight volcanic stones onto a green stick bent into a half-circle in the shallow water. Photographed in calm early morning conditions with the camera near water level, the half-circle's reflection in the perfectly still lake surface completes a full circle, embodying Hill's exploration of cyclical natural processes.
artworks.location: Whanganui Bay, Lake Taupo, New Zealand

artworks.title: Watershed
artworks.description: An exhibition and series of environmental sculptures examining the water cycle and climate change. Hill and Jones created ephemeral circular ice and stone sculptures in the mountains of New Zealand's South Island, each work representing a stage of the water cycle from glacial ice to flowing streams, documented through photography that captures the moment of perfect reflection before nature reclaims the materials.
